thread.title: Say goodbye to condensation and mould in your home by doing this one simple thing every night
thread.title_full: Say goodbye to condensation and mould in your home by doing this one simple thing every night

author: Mary Sworn
title: Say goodbye to condensation and mould in your home by doing this one simple thing every night
text:
Curtains are a great way to keep heat inside during the colder months. They’re also good for keeping out light if you don’t have shutters. Curtains are perfect for completing your home's style as well.
However, according to home experts, curtains could increase the chance of condensation damage to your windows. Don’t worry, there’s an easy fix.
You should open your curtains in the evening
Condensation can be a real problem in the UK during the winter. Many of us turn the heating up at this time of year to fight back the cold.
But this can increase the chances of condensation and mould growing in your home. Home experts at Screwfix explain that curtains trap heat, preventing windowpanes from getting warm.
This, in turn, leads to condensation as the windows are cold but the room is hot from the heating.
To stop this from happening, you should leave your curtains open for a while in the evening to allow your windows to warm up as well.
The experts said: ‘Keeping curtains open at night means the glass temperature will stay closer to the room temperature, so condensation won’t form.’
Or, if this isn’t an option, you can always switch to thinner curtains that don’t trap heat as much.
What are other ways to combat condensation?
There are plenty of other ways to keep condensation out of your home. You should always try to open your windows for a few minutes each day, allowing fresh air to enter your home.
When possible, dry your clothes outside. But we all know how difficult that is in winter in the UK.
If you can’t, make sure to dry your washing in a well-ventilated space and, if possible, use a dehumidifier.
Also, when cooking, make sure you turn your extractor fan on and open a window. Cooking, especially in the winter, creates a lot of steam and heat.
If you don’t control that properly, your home will become humid and condensation will slowly build up, eventually turning into mould if you’re not careful. Experts have revealed there's an ideal humidity level for you home.
Also, some plants can help tackle mould, especially in your bathroom.
5 FAQ about condensation in homes
1. Why does condensation form on windows?
Condensation occurs when warm, moist air inside the home meets a cold surface, such as a window. The moisture in the air cools and turns into water droplets.
2. Will leaving curtains open all night stop condensation?
Leaving curtains open can help reduce condensation by allowing heat to reach the windowpane, keeping the glass warmer and closer to room temperature.
3. Are thicker curtains bad for condensation?
Thicker curtains can trap more heat, which may make windows cooler and more prone to condensation. Consider using lighter curtains during colder months.
4. Does using a dehumidifier really help?
Yes, a dehumidifier removes excess moisture from the air, significantly reducing the chances of condensation and mould growth.
5. Which plants help reduce mould and humidity?
Plants such as peace lilies, English ivy, and Boston ferns are known to absorb moisture and improve air quality, making them ideal for bathrooms and kitchens.
